title: 108_s1633
content: The Act may be cited as the "Identity Theft Notification and Credit Restoration Act of 2003". Congress finds that the privacy and financial security of individuals are increasingly at risk due to the widespread collection of personal information by both private and public sectors. Credit card transactions, real estate records, consumer surveys, credit reports, and Internet websites are all sources of personal information for identity thieves. Identity theft is one of the fastest-growing crimes in the United States, posing a major law enforcement challenge as criminals use stolen information for fraudulent activities like opening credit card accounts. Identity theft is a growing concern, with criminals using stolen personal information to commit financial crimes. In 2002, over 160,000 people reported being victims of identity theft, costing consumers and the marketplace. Victims often spend years contacting various authorities and agencies to address each instance of fraud. The private sector and various entities have a shared responsibility to protect consumers from identity theft and fraud. Measures such as customer notification, fraud alerts, consumer access to credit reports, and other prevention measures can help in safeguarding sensitive personal information. Subtitle B of title V of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act is amended to include a new section 526, which requires timely notification to customers of unauthorized access to personal information. This is part of the shared responsibility of the private sector and various entities to protect consumers from identity theft and fraud. The new section 526 of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act defines a breach as the unauthorized acquisition of personal information compromising security, confidentiality, or integrity. Personal information for a financial institution's customer includes first name or initial, last name, and additional data. The term 'personal information' for a financial institution's customer includes the first name or initial, last name, and specific data elements like social security number, driver's license number, credit card number, and security codes. Financial institutions are required to notify customers in case of a breach of this personal information. Financial institutions must promptly notify affected customers, consumer reporting agencies, and law enforcement in case of a breach of personal information. Other entities must also be notified as per regulations. Financial institutions and other entities must promptly notify the financial institution of any breach of customer information. Notification must be made promptly upon discovery of the breach, taking into account law enforcement needs and measures to determine the breach scope. Notification required by this section may be delayed for law enforcement purposes if it would impede a criminal investigation. The notification must be made promptly after the law enforcement agency determines that it would not compromise the investigation. The form of notice can be provided in writing or electronically to the customer. Notification required by this section can be provided in writing or electronically, following the provisions for electronic records and signatures. If the number of affected customers or the cost of notifications is prohibitive, or if the financial institution lacks customer contact information, alternative forms of notification may be used. The Federal Trade Commission may use alternative forms of notification, such as email, website posting, or media notification, if a financial institution lacks sufficient customer contact information to comply with notification requirements for a breach of personal information. The Federal Trade Commission may use various forms of notification for breaches of personal information, including email, website posting, or media notification. Notifications to customers must include information about credit reporting agencies being notified and fraud alerts being placed on their credit reports. The Federal Trade Commission requires that credit reports of customers with a fraud alert due to a breach must have their authorization for any new credit issuance. Financial institutions must have a comprehensive information security program to comply with these regulations. The financial institution must have a comprehensive information security program consistent with regulatory standards. They must notify affected customers and consumer reporting agencies of any breach, and their internal security policies should include notification procedures in line with regulatory requirements. Customers can seek damages for violations, and injunctions can be issued against financial institutions. The financial institution can take legal action to recover damages for violations of the section, and injunctions can be issued for non-compliance. The rights and remedies under this section are additional to those available under other laws. Compliance with this section does not violate any other laws regarding financial information disclosure. The section limits financial institutions from disclosing information to third parties unless permitted by law. It does not impose new recordkeeping obligations on financial institutions. SEC. 4. INCLUSION OF FRAUD ALERTS IN CONSUMER CREDIT REPORTS. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to include a definition of fraud alerts, which notify users of potential identity theft and unauthorized credit issuance. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to include fraud alerts in consumer files upon notification by a financial institution, requiring express preauthorization from the consumer for credit issuance. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to include fraud alerts in consumer files promptly upon request with appropriate evidence of identity theft. Consumer reporting agencies are responsible for ensuring compliance with these requirements. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to include fraud alerts in consumer files promptly upon request with appropriate evidence of identity theft. Consumer reporting agencies must inform anyone requesting consumer credit information about the presence of a fraud alert in the consumer's file. The Federal Trade Commission will establish regulations for the duration and removal of fraud alerts in consumer files. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to include procedures for the removal of fraud alerts in consumer files. Violations include failure to notify users of fraud alerts and failure to comply with preauthorization procedures when issuing credit in the consumer's name. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to include procedures for the removal of fraud alerts in consumer files. Violations include failure to notify users of fraud alerts and taking adverse action based solely on the inclusion of a fraud alert in the consumer's file. SEC. 5. ACCESS TO CREDIT REPORTS AND SCORES. Section 612(c) of the Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to provide consumers with no-cost access to credit reports and scores. Consumers can request disclosures listed under section 609 once a year and every 3 months during a 1-year period with a fraud alert. Credit reporting agencies can charge a reasonable fee for disclosures related to fraud alerts. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to provide consumers with free access to credit reports and scores. Credit reporting agencies can charge a reasonable fee for disclosures related to fraud alerts. Financial institutions must provide notification for fraud alerts as required by the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act. Within 180 days of the Act's enactment, the Federal Trade Commission, in consultation with other financial regulatory agencies, must issue final regulations to implement the Act's amendments.
